literally “The Green One“. Said to have lived at the time of Abraham, drank from the fountain of life, and is called ist custodian. He is also said to symbolize the true guide. His name does not occur in the Qur’án, but some commentators identify him with the mysterious personage referred to in Qur’án 18:59-81.

School founded by ay-Aḥmad-i-Aḥsá’í. Among his doctrines, in addition to the imminent dual Advent, was that the Prophet Muḥammad’s material body did not ascend on the night of the Míʿráj.

Party (of ʿAlí). Partisan of ʿAlí and of his descendants as the sole lawful “Vicars of the Prophet“. The íʿahs reject the first three Caliphs, believing that the successorship in Islám belonged rightfully to ʿAlí (first Imám and fourth Caliph) and to his descendants by divine right. Originally, the successorship was the vital point of difference, and Islám was divided because Muḥammad’s (albeit verbal) appointment of ʿAlí was disregarded.

Originally, the successorship was the vital point of difference, and Islám was divided because Muḥammad’s (albeit verbal) appointment of ʿAlí was disregarded.

1) A “unityỵ or section of the Bayán. The Persian Bayán consists of nine Váḥids of ninteen chapters each, except the last, which has only ten chapters. 2) The eighteen Letters of the Living (constituting the Báb’s first disciples) and the Báb Himself. 3) Each cycle of ninteen years in the Badíʿ calendar. The word, signifying unity, symbolizes the unity of God. The numerical values of the letters of this word total ninteen.
